displayed_text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We also sort of know what side effects you’re going to experience to sort of see whether you can tolerate this. We have to adjust the doses about that. So that’s an approved drug that’s known to extend survival if people get the drugs, tolerate the drugs, respond to the drugs. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know those people can do well compared to those who don’t respond or don’t get the drug. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So chemo would be something that you know it could be given here, it could be given there, but it’s standard treatment. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have a clinical trial where we’re giving the chemotherapy and everybody gets an infusion two to three times a week. So- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: for someone coming from F___ may it may be too much to come in here that often, but we’re giving Vitamin C to half the people and half the people don’t because some data says that Vitamin C may reduce the side effects of the chemotherapy and also help the benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But we don’t know that. It could be just folly; it could be the truth-
